name: Colour TV Game
language: 4 games : squash, squash practice, football, tennis
coprocessor: Game selection and player options (power, speed, bat size, angle, serve, sound)
ports: RF TV video output, 2 x controller plugs
description:
This system is exactly the same as the Binatone Colour TV Game, marketed under a different name.

See this entry for more info...

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COLOUR TV GAME</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.rgbjuegos.com/" target="_blank">RGB Juegos</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD (JULY, 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Eric Buczynski for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advertising for the MZ 1500 (with the Quick Disk drive) in a Japanese magazine.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £149 IN JUNE 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #4 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Circa September, 1982.  This is likely one of the final Commodore advertisements for the VIC-20, as the C64 was soon to be launched.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PASOPIA 16 JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris"><a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Why paying more ?"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #9</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> As the American magazine 'Byte' commented, "for some time to come the 1040STF will be the clear leader in price/performance." </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Stop everything !''<br> ''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1983 <br><br> Advert said <br><br><font color="#666666"> Simple Isn't it?. The COMPAQ portable computer can do what the IBM Personal Computer does. To go.<br><br> It runs all the popular programs written for the IBM. It works for the same printers ans other peripherals. It even accepts the same optional expansion electronics that give it additional capabilities and fonctionality.<br><br> There's really only one big difference. The COMPAQ computer is designed to travel.<br> Carry the COMPAQ computer from office to office. Carry it home on the weekend. Or take it on business trips...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"MO5. Adventure built-in"<br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>cover</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Large achievement capability and high versatility with 64kb RAM."  <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROF80 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert from Pentasonic stores chain.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to its optional modem, the TO-7/70 could be connected to the Teletel communication network. This skilled photograph is browsing the Liberation (popular french newspaper) site. <br><br> But there are still no cables shown here ! How the whole system is running ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>More power for less money</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote>extract from the 1980 Coleco catalog<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
